title: Accelerating Development with AI Agents: Cursor & Aider Workflow
summary: A demonstration of an agentic coding workflow using Cursor and Aider to build, refactor, and test a TypeScript CLI application. The process highlights the transition from manual coding to high-level prompting, showcasing how AI tools handle boilerplate, error fixing, multi-file refactoring, and test generation to significantly multiply developer productivity.

steps.reasoning: Rapidly scaffolding a functional application (70 LOC) from a single 25-word natural language prompt.
Iterative refinement and debugging through conversational AI prompts to handle edge cases (missing files).
Preparing the environment for complex refactoring by explicitly adding relevant files to the agent's chat context.
Executing multi-file edits to separate concerns (moving logic to `crud.ts`) without manual copy-pasting.

steps.action: Implement new feature and generate tests
steps.reasoning: Simultaneously adding new logic (`delete_all`), updating the CLI interface, and generating unit tests across multiple files in one prompt.
Using predictive AI (Next Action Prediction) to catch and fix minor omissions in the user interface that the larger agent missed.
Validating that AI-generated features and refactors function correctly via automated testing to ensure reliability.
Leveraging predictive models to automatically propagate naming changes across function definitions and calls throughout the file.

key_takeaways: AI coding assistants can provide an estimated 8x productivity multiplier by converting short prompts into hundreds of lines of functional code.
Effective agentic workflows involve switching tools based on strength: Cursor for rapid iteration/prediction and Aider for complex multi-file refactoring.
The role of the engineer shifts from writing syntax to defining 'what to do' while the AI handles 'how to do it'.
Multi-file context and editing capabilities are essential for moving beyond simple snippets to maintaining real-world codebases.
